captions.text:
I do enjoy spending the week trying out new
indie games on Steam.

Brings back nostalgic memories of my childhood
when I used to dive into the part of the canal

near the sewage runoff pipes and then have
to spend the afternoon combing turds out of
my hair.

But every now and again amidst the turds I&#39;d
find a real treasure, like a used condom.

The sperm bank would pay a whole fifty pee
for one of those once I&#39;d finished chewing
it.

Man, it was great growing up upper middle
class.

So it&#39;s mostly been a pixelart jamboree this
week.

First I tried out Forager, a 2D pixel art
twist on the survival crafting grind &#39;em up

genre that presently occupies the bed of gaming
like a giant farting horse that won&#39;t stop
hogging the blanket.

Which I played until I realised that being
in a small environment smashing rocks is what

you do when you&#39;re in prison but without the
possibility of forbidden romance.

Then I tried out Dark Devotion, another 2D
pixel art twist on Dark Souls to add to the

pile, which discovered that once you take
the majestic scenery and sterling level design

out of Dark Souls all you have left is a game
moodily blatting you in the face with a rake
for eight hours.

Finally I settled on Katana Zero, a 2D pixel
art twist on hideous psychedelic violence.
Also, it&#39;s published by Devolver Digital.
Obviously.

Because the phrase &quot;2D pixel art hideous psychedelic
violence&quot; is to Devolver Digital what the

word &quot;walkies&quot; is to an understimulated dog
with poor bladder control.

In fact, I was thinking about listing the
features of Katana Zero as part of a hilarious

&quot;games published by Devolver Digital&quot; bingo
card, until I realised I was just writing
down features from Hotline Miami.

Pixel art and hideous violence, check, that&#39;s
the given.

That&#39;s the bloodstained arugula forming the
base of the horrible Devolver Digital salad.

A colourful retro aesthetic particularly themed
around retro forms of media in a way that

would give Quentin Tarantino an even bigger
priapism than the one he gets from his morning
bowl of discontinued breakfast cereal, check.

High speed gameplay where you can reload and
try again before your death rattle has even
gotten six inches past your tonsils, check.
Emphasis on soundtrack, check.

Somewhat obscure plot full of hallucinatory
moments strongly implying that the main character

is on enough drugs to fill out one of Michael
Jackson&#39;s average weekly prescriptions, cinnamon
chex with sausage on the side.

So to put it bluntly, Katana Zero is side-on
platforming Hotline Miami, but there&#39;s also

a bit of Gunpoint in there and a bit of Mother
Russia Bleeds if only because that, too, is

another strong contender for Devolver Digital:
The Game.
But does it have any ideas of its own?

Well, in Katana Zero you play a complete loser
with a Japanese sword, as referenced by the
title.

You spend your days hacking up assassination
targets given to you by your psychiatrist

because I guess punching a pillow wasn&#39;t doing
it for you anymore, and you keep taking a

magic drug that gives you the power to see
the future, but which is probably also turning
your brain to blancmange.

It&#39;s the kind of plot where you&#39;re a small
piece of a larger intrigue and none of your
manipulators ever tell you anything.

It might take more than one playthrough to
fully grasp it, so it&#39;s just as well that
the gameplay kicks arse.
Mostly.

Your precognition means that your failed attempts
are all framed as possible futures, and also

gives you a slow motion power, so at the end
of the level you see a replay of your successful

run as the timeline that actually happens
for realsies and all the slow motion stuff
plays at normal speed.

I&#39;ve often thought games with slow motion
could use something like this.

Doing something in slow motion isn&#39;t that
impressive because I can see how the game

has slowed down and extended the wheelchair
ramp to let my masturbation-addled thinking

keep up, but when the game then shows you
how what you just did looks from an outside

perspective, you can go &quot;Oh, OK, I&#39;m a fuckin&#39;
badass.

I mean, I suspected as much, I do masturbate
to a heroic degree, but it&#39;s nice to see it
confirmed.&quot;

Every enemy dies in one hit and you can dodge
and deflect bullets so on a successful run

you sweep through all resistance like a red
hot knife through a knife hotness inspection
and it generally kicks arse.
Just a shame there&#39;s so much plot in the way.

And now all the game developers will throw
down and stamp their baseball caps they got

free at GDC and cry &quot;he&#39;s officially impossible
to please.&quot;
Sorry.

I do like narrative, it&#39;s just I think this
is the Superhot and Quadrilateral Cowboy problem

where they came up with a lovely little original
gameplay loop but refuse to let it breathe

properly and keep killing the pace for the
sake of story moments.
Press right to walk over to the fridge.
Press X to heat up leftovers for tea.
Was this necessary, game?

I&#39;m happy to just assume my character picked
up drive-thru on the way home from the murder
spree.

Then there are a couple of gameplay asides
that fit into the core combat about as comfortably

as a hypochondriac into a vat of assorted
cattle guts.

One of your assassination targets flees on
a motorbike and we give chase on a second

convenient motorbike and suddenly we&#39;re playing
an arcade shooter from the early 90s where

we dodge slow, predictable missiles that move
like they&#39;re on wheelchairs when five minutes

ago I pressed the dodge button two frames
earlier than I should&#39;ve done and my knackers
were shot clean off right into someone&#39;s martini.

And then there&#39;s a stealthy bit, because that&#39;s
just what our high-speed drug-fueled katana

bisect-a-thon needs, a bit of hiding in a
cupboard with a sushi roll up my arse waiting

for a gap in the guard patrol routes, multiple
sargasms, and it&#39;s flat out fucking broken

because sometimes the guards positions reset
in such a way that there are no gaps in the

patrol routes and you run out the stage time
limit waiting for the fat gits to stop farting
visibility cones at the only door.
I say stealth section.

You&#39;re perfectly free to give everyone a wazikashi
prostate massage.

But my transparently evil handler told me
not to kill anyone, so obviously I tried to

do that &#39;cos otherwise the level&#39;s completely
fucking trivial and a game without challenge
is like fucking your own dog.
Where&#39;s the thrill of sexual conquest?

He&#39;s right there and up until this point trusted
you.

But I did a second playthrough to see what
consequences occur if you don&#39;t stealth it
up and the answer was &quot;bugger all.&quot;

Your transparently evil handler just calls
you a naughty boy, which depending on your
tastes, might be considered a reward.

This is far from the only time that the game
story implies that you&#39;re making a significant

choice that swiftly proves to be nothing of
the sort.

There&#39;s this one choice you have to make that
the game builds up across like three of its

interminable fucking dialogue trees and when
you finally get to make the choice it comes

down to &quot;Do you want to continue playing this
game what you paid money for, or do you want

to die, and then quit, and then, I dunno,
stick your head up a fish?&quot;
So let&#39;s tot up the main points.

Katana Zero is a game with heartbreakingly
good pixel art and animation with a neat core

gameplay loop that&#39;s just crying out for some
kind of infinite challenge mode so I can get

it clamped nice and tightly around my nipples,
but it needed to ease off the story pedal
a tad.

It&#39;s not awful, it&#39;s just got too much setup
and not enough payoff.

Like a wet T-shirt contest where they all
left their bras on.
